div.p:
XXX 334
Kerr Sambanza however had got
into a state of inebriation
from indulging in mead
similar to that which
Shinte presented ^ to us which is and much
more powerful than boyaloa
As far as we could collect
from his incoherent sentences
1 Shinte had said the rain was
too heavy for our departure
and the guides still required
time for preparation - He
himself was busy getting some
meal ready for my use
in the journey - As it rained
nearly all day it was
no sacrifice to submit to
his advice and
remain remain - Sambanza staggered
to Manenko's hut, she
however who had never
promised "to ^ love honour and
obey him", had not been
"nursing her wrath to keep it warm"
had not like a much
better woman in Scotland
been - "nursing her wrath to keep it warm"
so she bundled him cooly
into the hut & put him to
bed -

Kerr As the last proof of
friendship Shinte came into
my tent though it could
scarcely contain more
than one - looked at all
the curiosities - The quicksilver
335
the looking glass - books - hair
brushes & comb - watch &c &c
with the greatest interest
then closed the tent so that
no one ^ of his own people might see the
extravagance of which
he was about to be guilty -
He Then drew out ^ from his
clothing a string
of beads and the end of
a coneical shell which
is considered in parts
far from the sea of
2 as great value as the
Lord MayorsLord Mayor's badge - is in
London - He hung it
round my neck and
said "there now you
have a proof of my
friendship" - My men
informed me that ^ two
of these ^ such shells are so highly
valued in this quarter
that as evidences of
distinction, that for two
of them a slave might
be bought - & five would
be considered a handsome
price for an elephant's
tusk worth ten Pounds -
At our last interview old
Shinte pointed out our
Intemesi principal guide N Intemesi
a man about fifty
who was he said ordered
336
to remain by us till we
should reach the sea - that
I had nnow left Sekeletu far
behind and must henceforth
look to ^ Shinte him alone for aid
and that would always be
most ^ cheerfully rendered - This
was only his polite way
of expressing his wishes
for my success - It was
only the good words only of
3 the guides which were to
aid me from the next
chief (Katema's) on to the sea
There they were to turn but
he gave a good supply
of food for the journey
in front and after
mentioning as a reason
for letting us go even now
that as we had been
several days with him
no one could say we
had been driven away
from the town - he
gave a most hearty
salutation and we parted -
with the wish that God
might bless him -

337
26th Leaving Shinte's with
eight ^ six of the his men to aid
in carrying our luggage
we passed down the lovely
valley in which the town
stands in a wNortherly direction
then ^ passed a little to the West through
pretty open forest - and
slept at the ^ a village of a
Balonda headman named Capende
In the morning we had
a pretty fine range of green
hills called Saloisho on
and were informed that
4 they were well inhabited
by the people of Shinte
who worked in iron
the one of which abounds
in their hills

Mead The country through
which we passed possessed
the same general character
of flatness and forest that
we noticed before - The
soil ˅ is is dark with a tinge
of red - TheIn some places
it might be called red
and all seemed appeared very
fertile - Every valley
contained villages of
twenty or thirty huts
and gardens of manioc
which here is looked
upon as the staff of life
338
Very little labour is required for
its cultivation - The earth is
drawn up into oblong beds
about three feet broad
and one in height and
into them are planted pieces
of the Manioc stalk - at four
feet apart - a crop of
beans or earth nuts is are
planted between and when
these are reaped the
ground around the manioc
cleared is cleanred of weeds - In
from ten to eighteen months
after planting according
to the quality of the soil
5 the roots are fit for food
There is no necessity for
reaping soon, as it ^ the roots only
becomes become bitter &
dry at the end of three years
When a woman takes
up ^ the roots she thrusts in
a piece or two
of the upper a piece of a stalks into
the hole and a new
crop is thereby begun - The
plant grows to a height of
six feet and every part
of the plant is useful - The
leaves may be cooked
as vegetable - The roots are
abofrom three to four
inches in diameter and
from twelve to eighteen
inches long

339
There are two varieties of the
Manioc or Cassava - one sweet
and wholesome the another
bitter and actually containing
a poison but much
more speedy in its growth
then the ^ first other - This last
property makes causes
its perpetuation - When
we reached the village of
Capende on the banks of
the rivulet Lonatje we
were presented with so much
of the poisonous kind we
were obliged to leave it
6 To get rid of the poison
the people place it for
four days in a pool of
water - It then has
becomes partially decomposed
and is taken out stripped
of its skin and exposed
to the sun to be dried
When dried it is easily
pounded into fine white
meal closely resembling
starch which has either
a little of the peculiar,
taste, arising from
decomposition, or no
more flavour than starch
When intended to be used
as food this meal is
stirred into boiling water
340
They put as much in as
can be moistened - One
man holding the pot vessel and
the other stirring the porridge
with all his might - This
is the common mess
of the country - Though
hungry we could just but
manage to swallow it with
the aid of a little honey
which I shared with
7 my men as long as it
lasted - It is very unsavoury
(Scottice Wersh) and no
matter how much one
may ˅ stow away ingesteat, in two hours
afterwards ^ he is as hungry as ever
When less meal is employed
it is exactly like a basin
of starch in the hands
of the laundress, and to
the curious if the starch
were made from diseased
potatoes some idea might
be formed of the Balonda
potage which hunger alone
forced us to eat - Santuru
forbade his nobles to eat
it as it caused coughing
and expectoration

Our chief guide
Ntemesa sent orders to
all the villages around
341
on our route that ShintesShinte's friends
must have abundance of
provisions - Our progress
was impeded by the time
requisite for communi-
-cating the chiefschief's desire
and the preparation of
meal - We recievedreceived
far more food from
Shinte's people than
from himself - Kapende
for instance presented
two large baskets of meal
8 Three of Manioc roots steeped
and dried in the sun &
ready to be converted into
flour - three fowls and seven
eggs - with three smoke
dried fishes and others
gave with similar
liberality - I retugave to these
headmen small bunches
of my stock of beads &
the apology that we were
now on our way
to the market for these
goods - It was always
politely recievedreceived

We had an opportunity
of observing in our guides
much more punctilious-
ness in their manners
than in any of the tribes
342
farther south - They gave us
food but would not
partake of it in our
presence - when we had
cooked it - Nor would
they eat their own food
in our presence - When
it was cooked they retired
into a thicket and eatate
their potage then all stood
up and clapped their
hands and praised
Ntemesa for it - The
Makololo who are
9 accustomed to the most
free and easy manners
inheld out handfuls
of what they had cooked
to any of the Balonda
near but it was they
refused to taste - They
are very punctilious in
their manners to each
other - Each hut has its
own fire and when it
goes out they make it
afresh for themselves
rather than take it from
a neighbour - I believe
much of this arises from
superstitious fears - In
the deep dark forests
near each village as
already mentioned you see
343
the idols intended to represent
the human heads or lion
(alligator) or crooked stick
smeared with medicine,
or simply a small pot
of medicine in a little shed or miniature huts
with a little
mounds of earth
in them
with the
beards
But in the darker recesses
we meet with human
faces cut in the bark
of trees the outline of
which ^ closely resemble
those seen on Egyptian
monuments - Frequent
cuts are made on the
trees all along the paths
and votive offerings
are placed on branches
10 These consist of small
pieces of manioc roots
or cobs of maize - There
are also to be seen
every few miles heaps
of sticks which are
treated in cairn fashion
by every one throwing
throwing a small
branch to the heap in
passing - - or a few
sticks are placed on
the path and each
passer by turns from
his course and forms
a sudden bend to one
side in the road to one side -
344
It seems as if their minds
were in doubt & dread in
these secret recesses of
the forest and that they
were striving to propitiate
some superior being residing
their by their offerings

Berry The dress of the Balonda
men consists of athe skins
of some small animal
as the jackalljackal or wild
cat softened and hung before
and behind from a
11 girdle round the loins
The dress or undress of
the rather of the ladies is
of a nondescript character
but they were not
immodest - They stood before
us as perfectly unconscious
of indecency ^ of any indecorum in undress as we could
be with our clothes on -
But while ignorant of
their own deficiency they
could not maintain their
gravity at the sight of my
the nudity of my
men posteriorly - Much
to the annoyance of my
companions the young
girls laughed outright when
ever their backs were turned
to them

345
After crossing the Lonatje
we came to some pretty
villages embowered as
the negro villages usually
are in bananas - shrubs
and Manioc - and near
the banks of the Leeba
We haformed our encampment
in a nest of serpents
one of which bit one of
which one of our men
but the wound was harmless
The people of the surrounding
villages presented us
with large quantities
of food in obedience
to the mandate of Shinte
12 without expecting any
equivalent - One village
had lately come hither
from the country of
Matiamvo - They of
course continue to
acknowledge him as
paramount chief but
the frequent instances
which occur of people
changing from one
part of country to
another shewshow that the
great chiefs possess
only a limited power
The only peculiarity we
observed in these people
346
the habit of plaiting the
beard into a three fold cord.

Cazembe As ^ the Balonda chief Cazembe was pointed
out to us by Sambanza as
to the ^ N- E-North East and by E-East from
the town of Shinte, and
Sambanza and others
had and great
numbers of
people in
this quarter
have gone thither for the
purpose of purchasing
copper leglets made in
Cazembe's town, and
reportedreport the distance to be
about five days' journey,
I made enquiries of
some of the oldest
inhabitants of the villages
at which we were staying
13 respecting the visit of
Pereira and Lacerda to
that town - An old grey
headed man replied that
they had often heard of
white men before but
never had seen one
and that one came to
Cazembe when our
informant was young
& returned again without coming near
this part of the country
The people of Cazembe are
Balŏnda or Balŏi
and his country has
been termed Lŏnda - Lunda
or Lui by the Portuguese

347
It was always difficult
to get our guides to move
away from a place - They
wWith the authority of
the chief ^ they felt as comfortable
as kings-messengersking's-messengers ^ can be could be
could be
can be when
living at the
public expense can make themselves
and were indisposed
to forgego the pleasure of
living at free quarters -
My Makololo friends
were but ill prepared
drilled as yet and as
since they had never left their
own country before
except for purposes
of plunder they did not
14 take readily to the peaceful
system we now meant
to follow - They either
spoke too imperiously to
strangers or when reproved
for that were disposed
to follow the dictation
of everyone we met - When
Ntemesa our guide refused
to stir towards cross the
Leeba from
on the 31st January they would make
no effort to induce him
to go but I ^ having ordered them
to get ready and when
Ntemesa saw the
preparation he soon followed
our example and It
took us about four
hours to cross the Leeba
348
which is considerably smaller
here than where we left it -
Indeed only about a hundred
yards wide - It has the
same dark mossy hue - The
villagers lent us canoes
to effect our passage - And
having gone to a village
about three two miles from
the river I had the satisfation
of getting observations for
both longitude and Latitude
For the former the distance
15 between JSaturn and the Moon
and for the latter a meridian
altitude of canopus
Long-Longitude 22° 57' E-East Lat-Latitude 12° 6' 6" South

Wheeler These were the only opportunities
I had of ascertaining my
whereabouts in Londa
Again and again did I take
out mthe instruments and
just as all was right the
stars would be suddenly
obscured by clouds - I had
never observed so great
an amount of cloudiness
in any part of the South
country and as for the
rains I believe that
years at Kolobeng would
not have made my
little tent so rotten & thin
as one month had done
349
in Londa - I never observed
in the South ^ the heavy night
rains we had in this country
They often continued all night,
or, then became heavier
about an hour before
dawn - Or if fair during
the night, at that day drew
nigh an extremely heavy
still pouring rain fset in
16 without wandrning - Five
out of every six days had
this pouring rain, at at
or near break of day for months
together and they soon
beat my tent so thin -
that a mist fell through on
my face & which made everything damp,
The rains It wasere occasionally but
not always accompanied
with very loud thunder.
Next morning we had a
fine view of two hills
called piriPiri (Peeri) meaning
Two on the side of the
river we had left - The
country there is named
Mokwankwa - And there Ntemese
informed us one of Shinte's
children was born when
he was in his progress
southwards from the country
of Matiamvo - This part
of the country would thus
seem to have been but
350
inhabited by the people of
Shinte. - He told me himself
that he had come into his
present country by command
of Matiamvo

Here we were surprised
to hear English cotton cloth
much more eagerly
enquired after than beads
and ornaments - They are
more in need of clothing
than the Bechuana
17 tribes living adjacent to
the Kalahari desert, who
have plenty of skins
for the purpose - Here
animals of all kinds
are rare, and a very
small piece of calico
is of great value

1st Feb-February Ntemese sent in
the midst of the heavy
rains which continued
all morning to say he
was laid up with
pains in his the stomach,
and must not be disturbed,
but when it cleared up,
about eleven, I saw our
friend walking off to
the village and talking
with a very loud voice.
On reproaching him for
351
telling an untruth, he turned it
off with a laugh by saying
he really had a complaint
in his stomach, which
I might cure by slaughtering
one of the oxen and
allowing him to eat beef.
He was evidently revelling
in the abundance of good
food, the chief's orders
brought us - and he did
not feel the shame I did,
18 when I gave a few
beads only in return
for large baskets of meal

A very old man visited
us where with a present
of maize, - he like the
others had never before
seen a white man. - And
when conversing with
him, some of the young
men remarked that they
were the true ancients,
for they had now seen
more wonderful things
than their forefathers

One of Ntemese's
men stole a fowl given
me by the lady of the village.
When charged with the
theft - , Everyoneeveryone of his
Ntemese's party vociferated their his
352
innocence and indignation
at being suspected - Continuing
their loud asseverations
and gesticulations for some
minutes, one of my men
Loyanka went off to the
village, brought the lady
who had presented the
fowl as able to identify it -
then pointed to the hut
in which it was hidden.
The Balonda collected
19 round him evincing
great wrath, but he
Loyanka seized his battle
axe in the proper manner
for striking, - and placing
himself on a little hillock
soon made them moderate
their tones. - Ntemese then
called on me to send one
of my people to search
the huts if I suspected
his people - The man
sent soon found it, and
brought it out to the
confusion of Ntemese
and laughter of our
party - This incident
is mentioned to shewshow
that their much greater
superstition which
exists here, does not lead
to the practice of the virtues
353
We never met an instance
like this of theft from
a white man among the Makololo,
though they complain
of the Makalaka as addicted
to pilfering. - The honesty
of the Bakwains has been
already noticed. - Probably
the estimation in which
I was held as a public
benefactor, and in which
20 I was not yet known
to the Balonda, may account
for the sacredness with
with which my property was
treated. But other incidents
which happened subsequently
shewedshowed as well as this,
that thidolators are not
so virtuous as those who
have no idols -

Ker As the people on the banks
of the Leeba were the
last of Shinte's peopletribe
over which Ntemese had
power he was naturally
anxious to remain as
long as possible - He
was not idle but
made a peslarge wooden
pestle & mortar for his
wife during our journey
He also carved many
wooden spoons - and
a bowl - then commenced a basket
354
but as what he considered
good living was anything
but agreableagreeable to us who
had been accustomed to
milk and maize we
went on ^ forward on the 2d without
him - He soon followed
but left our pontoon
saying it would be
brought by the headman
of the village - This was
a great loss as we
afterwards found - but
it remained at this village
21 for two years and
when we returned a
mouse had eaten a
hole in it

We entered on an
extensive plains beyond
the Leeba at least twenty
miles broad and covered
with water ankle deep
in the shallowest parts
We deviated somewhat
from our N- W-North West course
by the direction of Ntemese
and keepkept the hills Peeri
nearly on our right
during a great part
of the first day - in order
to avoid the still more
deeply flooded plains
of Lobale (Luval?) on
ourthe West - These according
355
to Ntemese are at present
impassable being thigh deep
The plains are so perfectly
level that rain water
which this was ^ stands upon them for
months together - They
were not flooded by
the Leeba for that was
still far within its
banks - Here and there
as if dotted over the
22 surface are little islands
on which grow stunted
date bushes and scraggy
trees - The plains themselves
are covered with a pretty thick
sward of grass
andwhich conceals the
water and make the
flats appear as great
pale yellow coloured ^ prairies lands with
a clear horizon except
whenre interrupted here
and there by trees,
The clear rain ^ The water must have
stood some time for
on among the grass ^ for great
numbers of lotus flowers
were seen in full
blow - And the runs of
of water tortoises & crabs were observed - and otters also which prey on
the fish that
find their way to it -

The continual
splashing of the feet of
the oxen keep the feet
of the rider constantly wet
356
and my men complain
of the perpetual wetness
of the paths by which
we have travelled in
Londa as softening their
horny soles - The only
information we can
glean is from Ntemesi
who points out the
different localities as
we pass along and among
23 the rest to "Mokala /a
a Mama" his "mama's ^ home" - " house
It was interesting to hear
this tall grey headed man
recalrecall the memories of
boyhood - All the Makalaka
children follow ^ cleave to the mother in in
cases of separation or
removal from one
part of the country to
another - This love
for mothers
does not argue
superior morality
in other respects
or else Ntemese
any injunctions
his Mama may
have given not
to tell lies - The
respect however
with which he
spoke of her
was quite characteristic
of his race The Bechuanas
on the contrary follow
the father care nothing
for their mothers
but cling to their fathers
especially if they have
any expectations of
becoming heirs to his
cattle - Our Bakwain
guide to the Lake, Rachosi,
told me that his mother
lived in the country of
Sebituane but though
357
a good specimen of the
Bechuanas he laughed
at the idea of going so
far as from the Lake
Ngami to the Chobe
merely for the purpose
of seeing her - Had
he been one of the
Makalaka he never
would have parted
from her

We made our
beds on one of the islands
and were but wretchedly
supplied with firewood
24 The booths constructed
by the men were but
sorry shelter for the
rain poured down without
intermission till midday
There is no drainage for
these prodigious masses
of water on these plains
except slow percolation
into the different
feeders of the Leeba and
into that river itself
The quantity of vegetation
has prevented the
country becoming furrowed
by many rivulets or
"nullahs" Were the country
not so remarkably flat the drainage
must have been effected by torrents even
in spite of the matted vegetation
